title: Council of Jerusalem
description: The Council of Jerusalem was a conference of the Christian Apostles that decreed that Gentile Christians did not have to observe Mosaic Law.

title: Council of Nicea
description: The Council of Nicea was ecumenical council of almost all Christian churches.
location: Nicaea, in what is now Ä°znik, Turkey

title: Birth of Jesus of Nazareth
description: The birth of Jesus of Nazareth, who is later recognized as the central figure of Christianity. Although this is the event from which the modern calendar is counted, the exact year is somewhat debated, and likely it happened 3-5 BCE.

title: Ministry of John the Baptist
description: John the Baptist's ministry, including his call for repentance and baptism, is a precursor to Jesus' ministry and is detailed in all four Gospels. ca year 27-29

title: Crucifixion of Jesus
description: The crucifixion and subsequent resurrection of Jesus are central events in Christian theology, celebrated during Easter. They are documented in all four Gospels and referenced throughout the NT.

title: Conversion of Paul
description: Paul's conversion on the road to Damascus marks a turning point in the early Christian movement. He became one of its most influential apostles and authors.

title: Great Fire of Rome
description: Emperor Nero blamed Christians for the fire, leading to a severe persecution in which early Christians, including apostles Peter and Paul, were martyred.

title: Destruction of the Second Temple
description: The Roman destruction of Jerusalem and the Second Temple was a pivotal moment for Judaism and Christianity, marking the end of the Jewish sacrificial system and influencing the development of Rabbinic Judaism and Christianity.

title: Persecution under Domitian
description: Domitian's reign (81-96) included persecution of Christians, traditionally associated with the context for the writing of the Book of Revelation.

title: Edict of Milan
description: The Edict of Milan, issued by Roman Emperors Constantine and Licinius, granted religious tolerance to Christians, ending years of persecution and allowing Christianity to spread more freely within the Roman Empire.

title: Easter Letter of Athanasius
description: In his 39th Festal Letter, Bishop Athanasius of Alexandria lists the 27 books of the New Testament canon, marking one of the earliest known confirmations of the present New Testament canon.

title: First Council of Constantinople
description: This council reaffirmed the Nicene Creed and dealt with the heresy of Arianism. It marks a significant moment in the establishment of the doctrine of the Trinity.

title: Council of Ephesus
description: The Council of Ephesus declared Mary as "Theotokos" (Mother of God) and condemned Nestorianism, which held that Christ had two distinct persons. This council shaped the Christological debates of the early church.

title: Council of Chalcedon
description: The Council of Chalcedon defined the dual nature of Christ as both fully human and fully divine, an important development in Christology. It also caused a schism with the Oriental Orthodox churches.

title: Christianization of England
description: Augustine of Canterbury arrives in England to convert the Anglo-Saxons, initiating the spread of Christianity in the British Isles.

title: Death of Muhammad
description: The death of the Prophet Muhammad and the subsequent spread of Islam profoundly affected Christian territories in the Middle East, North Africa, and Spain.

title: Synod of Whitby
description: A significant meeting in the early English Church that decided the English Church would follow Roman rather than Celtic customs, influencing the future of Christianity in England.

title: Battle of Tours
description: Charles Martel defeats an Islamic army at Tours, halting the northward advance of Islam into Western Europe. This battle is seen as a key moment in the defense of Christian Europe.

title: The Great Schism
description: The formal separation between the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church. Differences in theology, liturgy, and authority had been building for centuries, culminating in the mutual excommunication of the Pope and the Patriarch of Constantinople.

title: First Crusade
description: Pope Urban II calls for the First Crusade, aimed at reclaiming the Holy Land from Muslim rule. This and subsequent crusades would reshape Christian-Muslim relations for centuries.

title: Fourth Lateran Council
description: The council formalized several important doctrines, including the definition of transubstantiation in the Eucharist and the requirement for annual confession.

title: The Western Schism
description: The Western Schism saw multiple claimants to the papacy, dividing Europe and weakening the authority of the Roman Church. It lasted until the Council of Constance (1417).

title: Fall of Constantinople
description: The fall of Constantinople to the Ottoman Empire marked the end of the Byzantine Empire, a major center of Eastern Christianity. It also led to the migration of scholars and texts to the West, contributing to the Renaissance.

title: Martin Luther's 95 Theses
description: Martin Luther nailed his 95 Theses to the door of the church in Wittenberg, sparking the Protestant Reformation and leading to a major schism within Western Christianity.

title: Formation of the Church of England
description: King Henry VIII declared himself the head of the Church of England, breaking away from the Roman Catholic Church in what is known as the English Reformation.

title: Council of Trent
description: The Council of Trent was the Roman Catholic Church's response to the Protestant Reformation. It clarified Catholic doctrine and initiated significant reforms in the Church.

title: King James Bible Published
description: The publication of the King James Version of the Bible, commissioned by King James I of England, had a profound impact on the English-speaking world and remains one of the most widely read versions of the Bible.

title: Peace of Westphalia
description: The Peace of Westphalia ended the Thirty Years' War and marked the beginning of a new order in Europe, with a greater tolerance for Protestantism and a shift away from religiously motivated conflict.

title: John Wesley's Aldersgate Experience
description: John Wesley, the founder of Methodism, had a profound spiritual experience at a meeting on Aldersgate Street in London, leading to the Methodist revival within Anglicanism.

title: Establishment of the Protestant Episcopal Church
description: Following the American Revolution, the Protestant Episcopal Church (the American branch of Anglicanism) was formally established, marking the development of a uniquely American form of Anglicanism.

title: Invention of the Printing Press
description: Johannes Gutenberg invented the movable type printing press in Mainz, Germany. This revolutionized the production of books, including the Bible, making them more accessible and leading to the spread of literacy and the Reformation. The Gutenberg Bible (1455) was the first major book printed with movable type, dramatically increasing the dissemination of biblical texts and theological ideas.
